story.text: MEXICO CITY Jan 2 Mexican stocks closed at their fourth straight record high on Tuesday, driven by dominant cellphone company America Movil (AMXL.MX) and cement maker Cemex (CMXCPO.MX). The benchmark IPC stock index .MXX rose 0.82 percent to 26,664.45 points, while the peso MXN= MEX01 firmed 0.31 percent to 10.7755 per dollar. Trading volume was low, with many investors in the United States sitting out the session on an official day of mourning for former U.S. President Gerald Ford. But the bull charged on in Mexico, with investors optimistic over the prospects for economic growth in 2007 and over the fourth-quarter earnings season set to begin in mid-January, traders said in Mexico City. Last week, stronger-than-expected U.S. economic reports on home sales, consumer confidence and Chicago manufacturing pointed to a more resilient U.S. economy than previously thought. Shares in Cemex (CMXCPO.MX), the world's number three cement maker and the biggest supplier of cement for U.S. construction firms, rose 1.61 percent to 37.20 pesos. Analysts at Santander said on Friday that more positive U.S. housing data would be a "positive catalyst for Cemex shares," and the bank maintained its "buy" recommendation for the company. Shares in America Movil (AMXL.MX), the most heavily weighted stock in the index, rose 1.11 percent to 24.65 pesos, while its holding company America Telecom AMTELA1.MX rose 1.89 percent to 99.76 pesos. Leading broadcaster Televisa (TLVACPO.MX) rose 1.97 percent to 59.65 pesos. On the losing end, shares in Bimbo (BIMBOA.MX), the world's no. 3 bread maker, dragged hardest on the index, shedding 1.48 percent to 53.20 pesos.
story.title: mexican stocks start year with record high close
